urls.title: Register now! EFSA Scientific Colloquium 26 on risk-benefit assessment of combined exposure to nutrients and contaminants through food
urls.description: Risk-benefit assessment (RBA) of food poses significant scientific challenges given the need to weigh the nutritional and health benefits of food types against the potential health risks from hazards such as environmental contaminants present in food. EFSA invites experts in this field to take part in a scientific colloquium on RBA in February 2022. The discussions and key outcomes of the colloquium will help to inform an update of the EFSA Scientific Committee’s guidance on RBA, published in 2010. The guidance will inform a wide-ranging assessment of the health risks and health benefits of...

urls.title: Resistance levels still high in bacteria causing foodborne infections
urls.description: A sizeable proportion of Salmonella and Campylobacter bacteria is still resistant to antibiotics commonly used in humans and animals, as in previous years, says a report released today by the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC) and the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA). In humans, high proportions of resistance to ciprofloxacin, an antibiotic commonly used to treat several types of infections, were reported in a specific Salmonella type known as S. Kentucky (82.1%). In recent years, S. Enteritidis resistant to nalidixic acid and/or ciprofloxacin has been...

urls.title: Antimicrobial resistance: What is the risk of spread through animal transport?
urls.description: EFSA has begun work on a new assessment looking at the risk of antimicrobial resistant bacteria spreading during animal transport. The assessment, which was requested by the European Parliament’s Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety (ENVI), will focus on the risk of resistant zoonotic bacteria spreading among poultry, pigs and cattle during transport to other farms or to slaughterhouses. When antimicrobial resistance (AMR) occurs in zoonotic bacteria – bacteria that can be passed from animals to humans – it can also compromise the effective treatment of infectious...

6/8 We include scientific considerations about the most important food groups in European diets, as recognised in national food-based dietary guidelines https://t.co/6EpI0hrVb6 where dietary roles & relative contributions vary across countries owing to dietary habits & traditions

5/8
Dr Alfonso Siani @siani56: “Public health importance should drive choice of nutrients, but decisionmakers may include them for other reasons eg to prioritise some foods even when science is not 100% clear an increase in their consumption is needed for public health reasons”

Given high prevalence of #overweight & #obesity in Europe decreasing #EnergyIntake is also of public health importance. But intakes of #dietaryfibre & #potassium are inadequate (& associated with long-term disease risks) so these should also be included

3/8

Our nutritionists propose nutrients & non-nutrients to consider in #NutrientProfiling models based on public health importance eg intakes of #SaturatedFats, #sodium, added/free #sugars are currently excessive & associated with long-term disease risks.

urls.title: Edible insects: the science of novel food evaluations
urls.description: Today’s batch of EFSA scientific opinions on novel food applications includes the first completed assessment of a proposed insect-derived food product. Our safety evaluations are a necessary step in the regulation of novel food, as our scientific advice supports EU and national decision-makers who authorise these products for the European market. Since the Novel Food Regulation came into effect on 1 January 2018, EFSA has received a large volume of applications, covering a wide variety of novel and traditional food sources. These include herbal products derived from plants, algae-based foods...

Our experts concluded #TitaniumDioxide (#E171) can no longer be considered safe when used as a #FoodAdditive. We have updated our safety assessment taking into account all available scientific evidence. #TiO2
https://t.co/4fvHmOByMw
@neoecocitoyen Worth noting that the physicochemical properties of TiO2 used for other applications can be different from TiO2 used for the food additive E171.

@neoecocitoyen Thanks for your question. As you point out, titanium dioxide is widely used as an excipient in medicinal products, mainly as a colouring/opacifier agent. As a food safety authority, our opinion focussed only on the use of TiO2 as a food additive.

Risk assessors like EFSA set Health-Based Guidance Values #HBGV, a threshold value indicating the safe level of a substance incl. #nutrients, for people & animals. What are they for? For decision-makers to set how much of a substance is permitted in #FoodAdditives, pesticides etc

Some #nutrients are regulated differently for use in EU in products like #FoodAdditives & pesticides e.g. phosphates, chlorides & copper. For consistency & coordination across all these areas our scientists developed approach to harmonise their assessment: https://t.co/NHFKEzpIc9 https://t.co/W7bf7Vz3Aj
